1.words: All right. Welcome to the conversation at Cortico's Local Voices Network and United Way of Dane County. Thank you for agreeing to participate. I'm starting to record and to make sure we're all on the same page. I want to share the four main purposes for this conversation. First and foremost, we want to create a new space and a new way for members of our community to listen, to and learn about each other's lives. Second, we want to offer ways for members of our community to connect with and build relationships with one another. Third, we want to support LVNs new and unique technology that offers a different way to hear and lift up the voices and concerns of members of our community, like you, and share them with elected officials, local policy makers, and members of the media. And lastly, to support United Way's desire to learn directly from our community to inform their work, United Way requested this collaboration with LVN to ensure that your voices and perspectives are available to help inform their fun strategic agendas. Following your conversations today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will be transcribed and added to a collection of the United Way Centennial Conversations hosted on LVN website. The audio recording will be available to journalists, public officials, researchers, and other participants and partners in project at Cortico and United Ways discretion with the goal of eventually making them accessible to the public. As a participant in this conversation you are providing consent to Cortico the operator of the Local Voices Network and United Way Dane County to use the recording in accordance with the goal to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. This is a public conversation and portions of it may appear in the local newspaper or website or to be broadcast in the local radio station or appear elsewhere, other forms of media. So please share only what you're comfortable with being heard by the general public. And if you agree, or if you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

29.words: Yeah. I grew up Catholic, which I know being Christian is one of the major religions in our society, but the town that I grew up in was pretty Jewish. I don't know the exact like proportion, but I grew up going to, and having a lot of Jewish friends and getting to learn their culture both in like my Sunday school and also from their religious services, which I think has helped me view my religion in a different aspect, but also to be accepting of people of different religions. But it also has sheltered me a little bit. The people from my area, we always say we grew up in a bubble and then when we get to college, that bubble has popped and I'm still learning and continuing to learn from different people around me. So in some ways I was privileged, but I also got to see some diversity, just not as much as what other people might've grown up seeing.

51.words: I agree with pretty much all you guys have said before, Madison is definitely a really interesting city, how it's both a college, town and the capital of the state it's in, but I spent most of this past summer up in Madison in my apartment. And one thing I didn't realize before when I was a freshmen and sophomore was how accessible Madison is. I really struggled with trying to figure out my grocery situation because there are a few like grocery stores on campus, but the better ones where I can get a little bit more food are further out. So I had to utilize the bike paths and I didn't realize how far they cross all over Dane County. So I would take bike rides just around just to see how else I can navigate. Plus the bus system, I think really helps with that too. Being able to explore outside of campus.

1.words: Welcome to this special community celebration conversation, hosted by Cortico's Local Voice Network, and United Way of Dane County. Thanks for agreeing to participate in this conversation, and I have begun recording. I'm just going to go over some things, just some key ground rules. Just to speak for yourself, and out of your own experiences. Allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time. Stay curious, pause, listen generously, and also stay present. I just want to make sure everyone's onboard with these guidelines, we just shared in the large group, and if there's anything you would like to add or change. Okay, perfect. Now we'll move on to some introductory questions, and to make this conversation a little bit easier, in the beginning, we'll use a modified circle. So we'll start with Jessie, Amy, and then go to Martinez. Please tell me if I got your names right. I'm ... Okay, perfect. We'll just use this modified circle to make things run more smoothly. I also want to mention, you can always pass, and we can come back to you, or if you just don't want to answer that question, you don't have to. Feel no obligation there. We're just going to do a quick round of introductions. So, we're just going to ask if you would share your first name, your gender pronouns if you're comfortable doing so, and also, in addition, just share a little bit of background info about who you are and a value that's important to you. I'll go first. My name's Anna. My pronouns are she, her, hers. A value that's important to me is honesty. I really value people being honest and wanting to share their ... Just what they think. I think it just makes it a lot easier and a lot better. This value relates to the community and why I'm here today, because where would I be if people weren't honest? I feel like you can only get so far, and if people aren't truthful, then you're just being held back in the past, and you're not really present, in the moment. With that, I 'll pass it to Jessie.

2.words: Hi, everybody. My name is Jessie. My pronouns are she, her. A little bit about myself, I'm a nurse. I'm born and raised in Madison, although I've lived some other places. I ended up coming right on back here, so ... I love Madison, and I love it so much, that I want to see it fulfill its potential. I would say that, a value that's important to me is, the idea of constant growth. I think that, that includes accepting mistakes that you've made in the past as growth, in addition to looking to the future and accepting the way that you are, as constantly transitioning.

21.words: I grew up outside Chicago, so I appreciate how Dane County allows me to be my city mouse, country mouse. I love the families, many of whom have come up from Chicago. There's just something about the families here that I love, and the children.

22.words: I like the resourcefulness of Madison. I'm originally from Milwaukee, but I've lived half my life here, in Madison. I went to college here, as early as 16 years old, so at 31 years old, my life has been installed and been built here, in the Dane County community. I just think that it's a place where you can really put some roots down and build something monumental. There are a lot of good resources, and a lot of good organizations that are working to change the image of our state, and also our national impact, as a participant in national politics, national education development, things of that sort. So I appreciate everything being here, that gives us the opportunity to build exponentially, and not in a slow fashion.

31.words: In the recent past, I worked with a group of students who went on a college tour, about a year or so back, and it was a group of students who emerged from an underprivileged environment, who got a chance to see ... Through a local church here in Madison, who got a chance to see what college looks like at a HBCU, or Historically Black College or University. For me, I thought that, that was really unique, in the sense that these students are getting a chance to see what their future could look like now. One of the guys actually moved on to do some acting work, and he's been featured on a couple national TV shows. So I thought it was really cool to build his desire for acting, through education. Then him go on to go to college, and then to start, early on in college, already embarking on an acting career. And it all started from some local work that was done here, and the community people, who wanted to see Black kids have access to Black, higher education. That's important to me, and I think education has been a theme here, and it's one of our items on the agenda for change. So I think that, that's really dynamic that kids get a chance to see something bigger and better, and then get a chance to manifest their destiny in those different realms.

About the idea that women don't get along, or don't support each other, or stick together. I think that, for some people, that really resonates. But she said, "I hear that, and that just really hasn't been my experience." I just remember, as a young person taking in these kinds of ideas that Black girls and Black women, we don't stick together, we don't, whatever. But as I have talked to my friend group from high school, that we're still tight, we're even tighter since COVID, we talked about this. 69.words: Here's what I would share. I have this unique experience. I intentionally left Madison schools after 23 years, where I just loved the children and loved what I did. I was given an opportunity to move to Sun Prairie, and I feel like I've gotten a new leash on life. But I no longer have the diversity that Madison afforded me, so I've lost that. But interestingly, I feel like I've gained a staff that has tremendous willingness for growth. A growth mindset to learn, and eager to want to be the change. Even though at our school, it's the, who we create when they leave our walls, that we aspire to. Because we just ... Our diversity is we have 20 children who identify as Black in this building, and that may be multi-racial Black, as African-American being one of the indicators. So we aspire to create strong individuals, as they leave our system, who are those global citizens. I don't know that, that same growth mindset was pervasive in Madison. I feel like ... And that's my experience, and the schools where I experienced. There were some schools that I have been touched by, as somebody whose been out of the classroom supporting schools, that have growth mindset. But some ... I was just ... I'm blown away by the growth mindset out here in the suburbs, I have to tell you. That's kind of what I'm saying. There's promise, and I just don't know why I was faced with something like a fixed mindset, like an entitlement, I guess, in MSD. By some.

74.words: As a community member, and I think as someone that's been transient and has kind of built, over the course of time, my livelihood in Madison, I think I realized that, there are a lot of students who are part of the pipeline programs at the university level, at the collegiate level, who are first gen, who are still experiencing this bastardization of their part of the state. So if you come from Milwaukee, or you come from Racine, Kenosha, Southeastern Wisconsin, and you come to Madison as a PEOPLE program scholar, or even as a POSSE scholar from LA, from Chicago, from DC, from all these other places, you come here ... I think there's a lack of engagement beyond the campus environment, for people to get acclimated to the city, and to the community, so they see it as a viable option when they graduate. That's kind of a little bit of brain drain, that I see here in Madison, when it comes to, specifically young, Black professionals, and young millennials of color, who are all different races and backgrounds, but who just don't feel the vibe, and don't feel the connection to the city, beyond the campus. So I think that's the area of opportunity at the higher level, at the higher education level, because we're getting all of these multi-talented students from around the world coming here, and then they leave here.

78.words: Like I said, I left Madison as fast I could, when I graduated from high school, to go to an HBCU. Even though I ended up ... I graduated from UW-Madison. Eventually, I came home and finished school here but ... It's hard. I don't necessarily have the perspective of ever thinking of Dane County as only the campus because honestly, partly because I was an adult student when I was at UW-Madison. So I didn't have those 18, 19, 20, early 20s experiences that so many UW-Madison students have. I didn't ever really think of myself as part of that kind of student community, but I definitely could see ... I think that for Black professionals and really any professionals of color to want to stay in Madison, I feel like they need to see themselves represented to a greater degree. I think that our communities of color seem to be hidden, to people who come to Madison looking for community and some place where people look like them, speak their language and check their food. You know what I'm saying? I think it's like, you have to have an inside tract to be able to find ... And I just think that thought really carries through, as far as, even the communities who are native to Madison, who are communities of color, feeling a part of the infrastructure. It feels like inclusion to somebody else's structure and system. I think that's part of the problem, and .... I don't know. As far as I know, it's been like that. It's like we have our own, but it's not really a part of where the power in Madison resides.

83.words: I grew up on the West side. This is the West side, East side thing too, because I grew up on the West side, but I really love ... I live on the North side now, I love it. I love it. I don't know. I think that, kind of how I talked about in my story, about the whole mindset and the reality that is created for you or presented to you, as a young person in Madison, is the limit. There's so many limits, there's so many boundaries, and there's so much that you are told that you can be and can not be, and these are your options, rather than really, that your options are limitless, and that you're in control. I think that, just like with parenting, it's like, I can tell you, this is an equitable society here, and we're all equal or whatever. But, I think that kids learn in practice and through their eyes that, that's not true. I just think that ... I knew that something wasn't right, and I just wanted to be in a place where it wasn't ... 88.words: I work on a committee, Downtown Madison Inc. has a committee, the Business Improvement District, where we're looking at the future of downtown Madison. What it needs to be, to be enjoyable by different, inclusive communities. Some of the ... We're doing a big landscape approach to ... Just a new vision. What id could really be, if it was perfect. If it was utopian downtown Madison, what it would look like. Some of the things that have come up, from just within the in group, is places where young professionals of color, where they typically congregate. We need different types of food venues downtown. We need different areas where Black women and young Black men can get their hair cut, or get it done at a salon. We need those comfortable spaces that normally exist within metropolitan, of Black folks and young people of color, where you might see in Chicago or Atlanta, Dallas, things of that sort, but not just here. It's just not here in Madison. So some of those small things, some of those cultural things, because culture is a meaning and people together. If we have all these people and they don't have a common understanding, there can be no culture, so we're looking to create a culture and craft a new vision for what it means to be a part of this community, and be a young person of color. Do you have the things downtown that signify, and are sign posts, for you to be comfortable in that environment? If you see a country club, you might think of a certain profile of a person that's going to be comfortable in that space, versus seeing a youth center or a skating rink, and some Black restaurant food nearby. So we have to create those spaces for people to coexist, and build, and feel safe. It happens in other parts of the country, it's just not happening here, just yet. But we're on the precipice of change right now. So yeah, I'm excited. I'm definitely excited for folks like Jessie to be back in this environment, for innovative thinkers like Amy, who's been around for a while, to think about how we can make this even better.

1.words: All right. So we're going to go ahead and get started here. And if the other person joins us in another moment or so, I will just leave space for them to do the introduction and repeat myself a bit. But welcome everyone, I'm so glad to have you here. My name is Adrienne, and this is a conversation for the city of Cambridge. We're working with a partner called Cortico and their local voice network, to record these conversations. And the video of this conversation will be discarded, but the recording will become part of a public collection, the audio, a public collection for the local voice network platform, and shared with the city council and the mayor's office directly. The Cambridge City Council has launched a community engagement phase of the search for the new city manager. And that city manager will start in the summer of 2022. If you're wondering what the city manager does, they are responsible for providing leadership and making financial decisions for all city departments and services. And our city manager recommends policies and programs to the city council, and implements the city council legislation. The office connects directly with Cambridge residents, hosting neighborhood meetings and responding to inquiries and requests. Always working closely with city council to improve quality of life in our community. As Cambridge moves forward in this important process, we need a media input from the Cambridge ... The broader public. Because that's going to have an impact on the lives of people in our city. And we want to be really intentional and thorough to make sure that we're collecting feedback, and we're collecting it in many different ways including surveys, interviews, and focus groups. This conversation isn't any of that, it's not a survey, it's not an interview, it's not a focus group. It's an invitation, an open invitation for you to share your personal experience, and provide us with a perspective on how the city manager process could affect the lives of Cambridge residents. So we're asking for your honest input and perspective, we're thanking you for joining us. And before I begin like a flight attendant, I need you all to verbally consent to the fact that as a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to the city of Cambridge to use this recording in accordance with its mission. And you understand that the conversation will become part of the Local Voices Network collection, whose mission is to foster conversation and communities and in the media, to improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree with this, I would ask you verbally say, "I agree."

We'll go around one at a time to share our stories. And please remember, since this is being recorded, not to use the names of other people when you tell your story. The city council hires the city manager to be the lead administrator for the city and in charge of all the city agencies. And so while the city manager is tasked with executing the city council legislation, there are ... They have the final say in a lot of matters, budgetary specifically among other things. Part of the reason that that was put into place was to avoid politics, essentially interfering in corruption. So this person isn't elected, which means that ideally they wouldn't be responding to corporate money in the same way that a politician could be. However, then you face the less democratic person that wasn't elected making the decisions in the city. And so there's a balancing act there. 1.words: Okay. All right. So I just have to read this beginning piece and then we'll get into the questions. Welcome to this conversation sponsored by Education Action Forum of Maine, and Educate Maine on Cortico's Local Voices Network. There are three main purposes for this conversation. First, we want to create a new way for community members to listen and learn about each other's experiences, values, and perspectives, especially around education. Second, we want to gather voices from all around the state to inform the direction of Maine's educational system. And third, we want to create a unique listening channel through which we lift up the voices and needs of a whole state, every county, in order to build a healthier public sphere, and education is a part of that. So we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing our personal stories from our lived experiences, rather than beginning the conversation with our position on issues. Following our conversation today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of the LVN collection. The data is owned by the Education Action Forum of Maine, and you will receive an email following the conversation, giving you access to it as well. What you say will be publicly available but only publicly identifiable by how you introduce yourself. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Education Action Forum of Maine, and Educate Maine to use the recording in accordance with the mission of Maine ED-250. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand, and agree to this, please say "I agree." So we have your [inaudible] consent to use it.

8.words: All right. First we have some conversation agreements. We ask that you feel free to pick up on threads from what you have heard others say here. Share fully and leave time for everyone to participate. Listen openly and ask questions when you want to know more about something that you have heard. Remember that it is not a debate or about winning, or even about finding an agreement, it's just about sharing experiences and ideas and listening to others. We are going to use the circle process, so we're just going to go around this way so that everyone has a chance to speak. And you can always say pass or ask for us to come back to you. To begin, let's do a quick round of introductions, just a sentence or two. So please share your first name, the county and town you live in, and a specific example of a time you felt you mattered to your community. Start right with this side.

And I think it's important that in a country that everyone gets a say in how or what's going to happen. And it's important to me because if you don't have that freedom and someone else is telling you what to do all the time, then how is that right? 57.words: Awesome. What role has school played in preparing you for your future and for the future you would like to have?

58.words: School has shown me how I don't want to live my life because there has just been so much rules and overbearing structure that makes it miserable for me and so many other of my peers and I feel like it literally dims my light and makes me not want to do anything. And everything that has propelled me forward has been outside of school, has been through different programs with adults that actually listen and care about me. And I've met really good people at my schools and I've made really good friends at school, but we have just thrived much better outside of the school system in America.

It creates a lot of problems. It doesn't do everything that everyone needs. I think we need a lot of education reform to get to a more reasonable place. I don't even want to talk about the subject matter of school because there's a lot of things that are left out for classist or racist reasons. There are a lot of problems with... We have some notepads, stress balls, water, candy, any masks, you can reach out to me, I'll put my phone number and my email in the chat now, but please reach out to me after this and then I can give you directions to our office, so that you can pick those things up. All right everyone, so thank you so much for joining this community conversation with the Public Health Course Storytelling Project. I'll start by just sharing some information about our purpose today and your role in this conversation and in this project. So we're almost two and a half years into the pandemic and the struggle around accurate, reliable and trusted information is still real. The initiative that you're joining today aims to change that, this conversation is part of an ongoing community powered initiative called the Public Health Core, and that's a citywide effort with the mission to expand the public health workforce by partnering with community groups and community health workers to eliminate the COVID-19 inequities through outreach and education and so the stories and the experiences that you share will be part of a citywide story library that amplifies the experience of you and other community members that are navigating the COVID-19 pandemic. We are recording the audio of today's conversations and the video portion will be immediately discarded, we'll get rid of the video and just keep the audio. 15.words: Awesome, thank you all. We believe that the people closest to the issue or problem are always the most important to hear from and to listen to. And so we would like to start our conversation today by talking about the challenges that you've come across during the pandemic in your communities and to identify any possible opportunities. What COVID-19 resources have been most helpful for you during the pandemic and why?

16.words: I can start this question, in my own experience during the COVID-19 pandemic, I can say the most helpful resources I found in my area was food pantries, I remember that this place in Western, that they give food every day, this a place already exists before the pandemic, but during the pandemic they extend the services and also I remember to went to get food from other resources, but the food that this pantry provide to the community was a food that we used to use in my Hispanic culture, beans and things that we are used to cook I found in that place, so I think this resource was very helpful for me.

18.words: I will go, so some of the financial resources that were really helpful for me, personally, were some of the student loan forgiveness programs, as well as just putting those student loans on hold, up until this day, a lot of people didn't have a surplus of money, some people lost their jobs and it was just really helpful just not to worry about that during the pandemic as we were worrying about so many other things and in that same topic, the stimulus checks were also really helpful, just so you don't have to worry about financial things, you can worry about the health and safety of yourself and your family and your friends and focus on that, as opposed to the stresses of finances, it's a little alleviation.

When the vaccine first came out, it was really difficult to find appointments and it was that really scary time, people were still getting extremely, extremely sick, so you felt this pressure to get it as soon as possible and there was just no appointments available, as well as before the at-home tests were available in drug stores and things like that, they were also really hard to get a hold of and then sometimes CityMD or other urgent cares had hour-long lines, I remember some people waited in line for seven hours just to get a COVID test, whether it was to go to work, school or to know if they needed to isolate from whoever they were living with, so just the access to those direct COVID resources were really difficult.

36.words: I think it was a bunch of small moments for me, as opposed to one key moment, so I have a lot of elderly members in my family, that I just wanted to get vaccinated for them, at the time the first dose of vaccines were coming out I was working in a hospital, so I was lucky enough to be offered one of the earlier vaccines, so I knew that I had to do my duty to my community, where I live and to my family and friends, and since I was able to get the vaccine, do that for everyone and not just myself, and then also just being in a hospital, seeing all my friends working around the clock, as nurses or as doctors, and putting themselves at risks, so I also did it to honor them as well.

51.words: I think by reducing barriers, so I know some of the organizations in my area, when the vaccines first came out, they were really focusing on getting people who don't have cell phones or computers appointments, because you couldn't call and make an appointment, so they reduced that barrier or they found individuals, rides, whether it was through a ride share like Uber or they themselves took an individual to get vaccinated, so the communal organizations really were identifying the needs and the barriers and did their best to alleviate those barriers. So I think that allowed for a lot more people to get vaccinated when they might not have otherwise.

60.words: So for me, I was actually working with a community organization through a council member's office in my area, helping to get elderly individuals vaccine appointments, so I was working with my first individual, she was actually in concentration camps during World War II and she was elderly and couldn't leave her house, but didn't have a computer, didn't have a cell phone, so I spent days trying to get her an appointment, finally we got through, got her an appointment, her niece took her to that appointment and they were just both crying and so thankful that they could get in and then the niece actually came to my apartment and dropped off brownies as a thank you, and just a really, really nice story and we actually keep in touch, still to this day.

71.words: I think that the post pandemic future is... We don't know how they will come, because see around, outside on the street buses, the people is not using mask anymore, very curious, last Saturday in the train, I'm not used to use the train often, but last Saturday I saw this CDC flyer that say "Mask is not required, but is recommend to use", but people don't use the mask and now it's time to other virus, because the light flu, because the cold weather, I think, in my own opinion, I think that the future will be that more people going to be infected, because if they don't use mask and the cold weather coming, the flu too, it's a lot viruses around, I hope the people is thinking to get all vaccine and that can be helpful, but if the people continue to use the mask, at least inside the train or buses, this will be more hospitalization or more people infected.

1.words: Thank you everyone for joining us this morning. I'll have you guys do introductions in just a minute or two after I read the introduction that we have. So welcome to this conversation on Cortico's Local Voices Network sponsored by Education Action Forum of Maine and Educate Maine. There are three main purposes for this conversation. First, we want to create a way for Mainers to listen and learn about each other's experiences, values and perspectives, especially around education. Second, we want to gather voices from around the state to inform the direction of Maine's educational system. We have conversations for community members, educators, youth and people and in major Maine industries. Third, we want to create a unique listening channel through which we uplift the voices and the needs of the whole state, every county in order to build a healthier public sphere. And education of course is a critical part of that. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing your personal stories from your lived experiences rather than beginning the conversation with our positions on issues. Following the conversation today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of the Local Voices Network collection. The data is owned by Education Action Forum of Maine and you will receive an email following this conversation, giving you access to the recording as well as all of the other recordings that have been part of this project. What you say will be publicly available but only publicly identifiable by how you introduce yourself. So please introduce yourself only with your first name and your role. Of course, you can introduce yourself with your last name if you want to, but typically we're asking people to do first name. And we have a little agreement to be recorded that I'm going to read. And after I read it, if you all agree, if you could say I agree, that would be great. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Education Action Forum of Maine and Educate Maine to use the recording in accordance with the mission of Maine ED 2050. The mission of Maine ED 2050 is to bring communities, educators, and youth together to discuss how education and schooling can be designed together for personal, civic and economic thriving in the next few decades. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve or understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

29.words: I think one of the biggest pieces that I've seen as a shift has been away from the sad shock trauma approach to education and knowledge around mental health. For so long it was essentially scaring people out of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, scaring people out of being depressed and anxious. The wonderful advice that I think everyone is heard at some point, well have you tried just not worrying about it? Has always been the go-to fix for mental health. Whereas I feel like we've seen a time with a shift towards hope, health and strength, which has been something that's really important to our team in being able to have that shift in messaging because that's going to build that longer term resilience that's going to provide a whole lot more accessible messaging for our young people, honestly as well as adults because it's not othering the situation, it's instead inviting people in to have conversations around what's going well, how to grow, what's going well, and how it's okay for that to look different for every person.

28.segment_words: I think one of the biggest pieces that I've seen as a shift has been away from the sad shock trauma approach to education and knowledge around mental health.
28.linked_words: So our next question is reflecting on your time working in youth mental health, what are the ways in which working in this industry has changed and how have you been expected to grow, learn, or change?

30.words: From doing youth mental health first aid trainings in particular, we meet a lot of community members, teachers, individuals in and around the school. And a concept that came up in our trainings is adults, staff, teachers are so scared to say the wrong thing, they're not saying anything at all. And that's not a blame by any means. I just thought that was really impactful to hear, because mental health, there is such a stigma around it still that it can be really scary to approach these conversations. If you notice warning signs in a young person and you want to help them and not knowing exactly what to say. And so I think for me personally, what I've learned, what I've grown with is you can literally say, "Hey, I'm a support. I noticed some changes and I wanted to check in with you." I personally overcomplicate things and I'm not saying it's a simple topic by any means, but even though it's a scary conversation, being a support, being that trusted adult in someone's life is so much more important than saying the right thing. And so that was a really powerful thing for me to hear and to learn and kind of grow with. And working with young people directly. They want honest communication. I'm not saying treat them like adults because they're, they're young people, they're still learning, they're still growing, but being honest with them, "Hey, even though I'm an adult, I don't have all of the answers, but I want to help you. I want to be there for you." So this was a big learning point for me and an adjustment in making sure that I am providing the best support for young people while letting them know that, hey, again, we're human at the end of the day and we're going to do the best that we can do.

28.segment_words: I think for me personally, what I've learned, what I've grown with is you can literally say, "Hey, I'm a support. I noticed some changes and I wanted to check in with you." ... 31.words: For me as a person who is newer in the youth mental health professional field, I think I've been working in a time that has been perpetuated by change with the pandemic, that we are just experiencing constant change in how the field operates, how we're dealing with mental health. And I think I've been seeing a lot of positive changes in the fact that we're having a lot more open conversations. People are recognizing that mental health is a significant issue, whereas when I was a youth, not too, too long ago that those conversations were not happening. 32.words: I would definitely agree with that. Thinking about the growth learning and changing definitely around that flexibility and willingness to adapt to the needs in the moment. I can't think of how many times that we have met with schools with a plan going in for a couple hour session with them on something and those plans getting completely derailed because we need to talk about self care with the adults because they might be approaching burnout at such a high rate that if we don't slow down and have that conversation, they're not going to hear and absorb any of the other content and information that we're going to be sharing with them. We can provide all of the awesome knowledge, resource, skills, abilities to folks, but if they're not in a space to hear it, to be able to internalize and reflect on that themselves, then it's gone in one ear out the other. And so being able to adjust and go with the flow a whole lot more than I feel like in the past has been needed. In terms of growing, something that I encountered when learning more about pronoun usage in conversation and introductions ongoing, is this concept of messing up gracefully. And that has just really resonated with me in all of the ways. So definitely comes out of the conversations and learning around pronouns, but it's something that I feel is important that we take and apply to all areas of our lives. There's such this focus on, as adults, we've got to do things right the first time. We've got to be perfect, knock it out, not have any struggles or problems or difficulties to overcome or overcome something. And instead by having that willingness to try something, try something we might fail at, commit and move forward until we learn that, hey, that wasn't the right way. That wasn't the right thing. But being able to be humble and secure enough in ourselves to be able to acknowledge that, hey, I said the wrong thing there. I'd like to make it right by doing X, Y, Z, I'm sorry, moving on. Taking ownership when we misspeak, when we misstep, when we don't act, when we should have acted. Again, acknowledging the human component to each of us, but also taking that responsibility within ourselves to speak up and to shine a light on that, to really normalize that none of us are operating at a hundred percent, none of us are perfect walking around and that's okay.

40.words: I think that can be a whole span of things. Some days it's thinking about what the statewide data is going to look like, that comes back measuring where young people's mental health is across the board. Sometimes the most awesome piece of success that we might see is having a session with young people on Zoom like we were doing over the pandemic and having a young person in a really rural community sending a direct message saying, "Wow, I didn't know that there were resources for LGBTQ plus young people that could be accessed online. That's so cool." Or hearing after talking with a group of sixth graders that one of them after our conversation did go to their social worker and say, "Hey, I'm worried about my peer." On one hand I have dreams about the big successes that we're going to see that the more information that we get out there, that the bigger results that we're going to see, which is cool, awesome. But really that success for me is when we hear about that individual, when we can touch that individual person in such a positive way, either connecting them with a new resource, keeping them from feeling isolated, empowering them to speak up and use their voice that they have, that's so powerful. And do you expect other factors to play a role in changing the mental health, but specifically youth mental health industry?

46.words: In terms of local trends in Maine, we just recently got the Maine integrated youth health survey data from fall of 2021, released by the Maine CDC. To be totally honest, I have not yet had the opportunity to meaningfully dig into that. We have another survey for that coming up in spring of 2023. And between those two pieces, I think that's going to be very telling for us on where our young people are at. With the pandemic and the light that has been on mental health, I feel like there was a really big opportunity for positive change to happen. And as people have re-acclimated in, whether we call this the ongoing pandemic, post pandemic or whatever language it is that each person is using these days, I feel like as we've started to return to the sense of "normal", we're starting to see a pullback from understanding of youth mental health already, unfortunately. I think that the drive is there for more people to have that knowledge, awareness, and desire to do better. But I'm starting to see systems pulling back and trying to refocus on two things that were more traditionally a focus like with schools being pulled back to focusing solely on their standards. Whereas previously, maybe the administration would have supported more education around mental health for their staff. And unfortunately as a state, as a whole New England area as probably a whole country, we don't have a mental health system that is super functional yet. And I think that, that's something that is on a positive track or I'm hopeful that it is. But with the way that our system is set up right now, it is very reactive and we don't have enough providers. And the ones that we do have are working their hardest in doing their absolute best. And I am so grateful to them. But we look around the state and we see wait lists that are out of control. I hear about folks that have been on waiting lists for over a year for some services. And it's not that anyone's doing anything wrong, there's just not enough. And I think that how we move forward from this space right now is going to be very telling for what things are going to look like over the next couple decades. We're in a position to have legislature reevaluate where reimbursement rates are for Medicaid across the state. For insurance companies, on what kind of responsibility they have to serving people with mental health needs. How accessible that can be to people is unfortunately tied to financial status. If people don't have insurance or don't have access to Medicaid, that's not a feasible option for folks to be accessing ongoing professional support more often than not. And even those that do have access to those insurance coverage is not always ideal. And people are limited by having to have a specific diagnosis, often, diagnosis often that would provide them a prepackaged treatment plan often, it feels like. And again, that's not on the providers, I see that as an insurance problem that is directly impacting the care for not only our young people, but people at large. And I think that as we see this younger generation come up to voting age and being able to be more civically involved, I am hopeful that we're going to see some larger systemic changes that's going to impact really everyone's access to mental health services supports and the way that we view mental health, to be able to have it as an ongoing, open, honest conversation. Not this thing that gets swept back under the rug because we've returned to what we believe to be normalcy. So I'm always optimistic that we're headed in a better direction, but also realistic in that our system is not perfect. The individuals that are in it are trying and working their best, and I appreciate that to no end, but we always have room for growth and improvement.

47.words: I would agree that I think the biggest trend that I'm seeing that's having an impact would be the access to resources in that Maine does not have the resources necessarily to meet the needs in the way that we would like to see those wait lists can be incredibly discouraging to people who are trying to get help. It could cause them to feel like they're being rejected even though that's not really what's happening. So those things can butt heads in ways that are not what we want to be seeing, but hopefully there will be things in place in the future that might mitigate some of those issues with resources that we have in our system at the moment. And then to add on to another thing that I see, other factors playing roles in youth mental health is the conversations that youth are seeing on the political national level. It has a very big impact, and particularly in this moment, thinking about like the LGBTQ community. Consistently, studies have shown over the years that they are disproportionately affected at higher rates where they're experiencing depression and they're having suicidal thoughts more often. I believe that the rates in the MHSS data that came out recently is that for LGBTQ individuals, it's around 40%. That shifts depending on which group we're looking at. But 40% I think is the lowest number of those groups. And so when we're then seeing conversations on a national level where there's pushback against having conversations in schools, then that's affecting those youth because it's affecting their safety at school, which should be a safe place for them. So that's just one example I think of many that we could pull out, but that is one factor that immediately came to mind for me.

Let me rephrase that. What ideas do you have for how youth mental health organizations can work more fruitfully together with schools and other learning environments?

49.linked_words: do you feel like pursuing a career in mental health and specifically youth mental health is valued in Maine and in your communities?

52.words: More. More agencies, more providers, more resources to be able to offer to the schools. But these schools need more time, more funding, more teachers, more paraprofessionals, and it feels like both systems are in crisis mode in their own right. And trying to get that collaboration and prevention work going together when people are just trying to get through the day to make it through makes that really difficult. And so I think that when we have administrations in school and when we have teachers and professionals and other staff that are at schools that are wanting to not just get through but feel interested in learning more, when they feel supported in learning more. So when the messaging is coming down from them or from their powers that be, that it is a strength to learn more, to be an updated kind of support for the young people, not just the messaging of get through the day, we'll make it to tomorrow. That can make a huge difference in the partnerships.

51.linked_words: What ideas do you have for how youth mental health organizations can work more fruitfully together with schools and other learning environments?

53.words: We have a wonderful upstream suicide prevention program that we're working to get into as many Maine schools as possible. Right now it's really strength based and looking to the strengths that you have available to you to help work through life ups and downs, everyday stressors that are showing up for you. And we've found that schools are really excited about this program and want to be super invested. However, the lack of subs, the lack of time to be able to be away from the classroom, to be trained in this program and feeling like one more thing added to their plate has really made them hesitant to bring the program to schools. And so as Kristel said, I think more was a great way to sum that up. More time, more subs, more resources, more support so that they are able to connect and have these programs that they want to have, but the access accessibility is not right there for them to be able to get these programs going.

59.words: As an aside with the technology piece, this has been such a great opportunity these last couple of years to be able to see people have the opportunity to use technology for their benefit of learning more and engaging in different ways. We all can appreciate that we were all headed in this direction anyways to be able to access online learning. But having that speed up of things was incredible in so many ways. Terrible that it came about the way that it did. But I'm glad that we now have been able to see trainings that we would've previously held in one community doing a gatekeeper training in northern Maine. We would have one population that would be at that training, whereas now if we hold something virtually, we can get such a more robust group together. We can have people that are working in schools in southern Maine, northern Maine, eastern Maine, western Maine, and there is so much similarity, but also such different perspectives that come together that way that really allow for some creative thought into how we're navigating all of the things in schools these days. And it's really great to see that different learning styles are being acknowledged in adults, finally. So to be able to see that shorter learning blocks are super effective, so by people having noticed that in adults, that's filtering down to acknowledging that our young people definitely have different learning styles and that it's not a bad thing, that we find what works for an individual and help them be successful with that. That's not making things "too easy for them". It's about helping them be successful and be the best version of themselves they can be.

Just overall, it's going to help going into adulthood and navigating stressors that are going to show up naturally. 63.words: This is the first thing that came to mind for me is actually quite different. Home economics, the programs were completely gutted. So when I was in high school, there were no home economics courses. We were not, that traditional students learning how to cook, learning how to do basic things to take care of themselves as adults. The financial literacy course in my school, the culture around it was the course for people who didn't know how to do math, which is completely wild to me because it was how do you write a check? How do you do your taxes? It was such important things. And then so kids are turning 18 and they're expected to take care of themselves in the world, which is an incredibly stressful experience because they're not being taught those basic foundational skills. Which I think kind of echoes back to what Kristel said at the very start of this, that food, starting with something like food and then building up. To be able to start with teaching our kids how they need to take care of themselves without focusing on where are they going professionally, where are they going academically first. I think there's been a huge priority on academic achievement and professional achievement with that has thrown some of those basic self-care things to the side a bit. And I'd love to see those traditional things come back.

61.segment_words: Which I think kind of echoes back to what Kristel said at the very start of this, that food, starting with something like food and then building up.

64.words: I'd definitely agree with that. And also there's this assumption around our young people that you need to treat them like children, just treat them. They don't know anything through their 18th birthday. And then we hoist them forward and say, "Well, why didn't you know how to do that?" And so there needs to be this bridge of encouraging young people to be able to be a part of conversations and holding that space for them to be a part of decision making so that there's more things happening with them than at them. And so that transition to adulthood is going to be a whole lot smoother if the first time that they are making education decisions is not when they're a thousand miles away from home for the first time, trying to pick a college degree that's going to cost them an arm and a leg for the rest of their life. Thank you student loans.

66.words: We need to be able to have the space and room to be able to help our young people as whole people, not as checklists, not as standards meeting, not as whatever other procedure might be in place. We need to be able to give our parents, caregivers, teachers, paraprofessionals, every other individual that is connecting with our young people to give them as much of the tools and resources and time in space to help our young people. To stop putting this culture of busy on everyone. To be able to slow things down some so that an individual can be seen as a whole person, not just a student that happens to be in a math class today, or a difficult teenager that works in the grocery store that's bothering you that day, but rather as whole people with whole lives and experiences that are going to need different supports in different ways at different times.

69.words: Absolutely. As a quick add-on to that, I think of recently, Libby and I met with a group of students that were expressing some frustrations with the culture at their school that there was a culture of physical violence at this school and they were worried about how the school was responding or not responding. And they took it upon themself to put together these flyers, posters that they wanted to put up around the school to encourage communication. And it was done in such a respectful manner. It was very accessible in the way that they were designed. It was wonderful to see a young person take it upon themselves to do something like that, to essentially make an action plan and want to follow through on it. The difficulty that we saw in that moment was this young person came to the school so excited to be able to hopefully do something about this problem that they're seeing. And instead of being met with excitement or, Wow, great job with that. Let's see how to integrate that. It almost felt dismissive. And that's where a lot of our problems are stemming out of. We have adults that are working with young people that got into it for all of the right reasons, and their heart has been there through everything, but they have been stretched so thin, and they have had to give everything and have more asked of them on an ongoing basis that they don't always have enough left in them to be able to make that connection, to be able to be that resource and support. So we need to build out these systems in a meaningful way that makes it sustainable, that makes it so these people that care and want to help our young people can do that work. And that is a huge shift that we need to make.

194.words: What we learned? First of all, I think we're learning now. There's a lot of emotional backlash. Even more in a way than physical backlash from COVID and from, I don't know if you could say the way it was dealt with, but just the fact that you're taking a community that their basic way of life is interacting with each other every single week and always. And then you dump in all the holidays and then it becomes three times a week and the men go to pray three times a day. You're taking such a community, you're just telling them stay in your houses. The emotional backlash of being told to not go anywhere and not talk to anyone and not do anything, I think is coming out now more than before. Because everyone's just dealing with the very real physical ramifications, which were people getting sick, people dying. I've done a lot of work around really kind of building academic enrichment and personal development programs in nontraditional spaces, particularly as it relates to serving communities and people of color, black folks. Blacks and Latinos, if they identify as such. That's been my overall focal point. My basis is project management. I use project management and education as kind of a dual pathway to manifesting, not manifesting, to facilitating these sorts of activities that help communities. A time that I feel that my participation really made a difference, pretty active wherever I am, because I feel like I have a debt that I owe to any community in which I reside, so the one example I'll give you, I can't think of a current one, oh, yes I can. I recently did voter outreach, when we had our last election. At the last minute, I was called on to be an election judge, because there was actually a person that was scheduled in the space that I wound up working on, who left and didn't come back. So I stepped in, and folks came in to actually vote, very appreciative that there were people there, because there was a pretty significant shortage. That made me feel like I was contributing to the community, and contributing to the overall focus of equity.

17.words: Well, my background actually is in finance, but I have been educating people in different arenas for a very long time. Due to a need for my children, I came to start working in the school system as what they call a community organizer and working with parents, and helping parents to understand how important it was to be a part of their child's education. But it happened, really, because I had a child that went into the public school system with an IEP, and I noticed the inequities that were happening. There was nobody there to really support me, and they kept telling me all these different things, that they wanted to put my child on medication and everything. It wasn't working for me, I was like, there's got to be another way, other than to have a child constantly on medication and walking through life looking, in my opinion, looking like a zombie. I became very interested in advocating for parents who didn't know any better, and that's what I do now. I actually advocate with parents and help parents to go in and help teachers. But the real thing that helped me and my moment that made me know that I made a difference is when I started doing this work, I went on the other side of the door, because I can tell you what happens as a parent when I'm outside of the school. I had no idea what was on when I walked in the inside, and I saw how the teachers are having to go through different things and not having the support, 30 kids in a classroom, one teacher, no other support, and five of them have an IEP, or 10 of them have an IEP, and she's expected to monitor these children as well as teach the other 20. It's not happening. And if it is happening, it's not happening in an efficient manner. What I do is I help parents to go into the classroom to support the teacher, and one parent came to me, who had two children that had an IEP, and she thanked me, and she said, "You don't know, I didn't understand, before I came here. You don't know what a difference it makes for me to actually understand how important it is for me to be in here with this teacher and to help this teacher and to help this teacher with, even the other children," because once my parents go into the classrooms, they tend to have a whole different aspect of what the school system is really about, and they fall in love with the kids, and the kids, again, enrich them. They come back and they say, "Thank you for giving me this opportunity. You made a difference. Thank you for letting me understand what really goes on," because we have a lot of parents that will complain on the outside of the school door, but they never bother to get involved. They never bother to see what's really happening. They never bother to see is it that the teacher just really doesn't want to get back to me, or the fact that she is so overwhelmed she can't. That's happening in our schools, in our community, but if you go up north, there's all kinds of teachers' aides, and there's such an inequity. I see parents that are leaving CPS and going out to different suburban schools, because they just want to give their child a better opportunity. I'm going to be honest with you, I was one of them. My child started out in Orland.

20.words: Right, I can imagine. Wow, thanks for sharing that. Yeah, it's a lot. Parents aren't really encouraged to be involved either, and it's not made convenient for parents either, especially if you work two jobs, you work shift work. That's a whole, well, thank you for the work that you're doing with parents, because they need you. I guess my story is, I don't know, sometimes I wake up and think I'm not making a difference most mornings. There's been a couple times where, and the one that I'll share is one of my last public school positions, I have worked for CPS. I still work in CPS now, as a community partner, but I was up at Evanston Township High School, where I was for about six years, and I was a district-wide administrator. I was their first literacy coordinator, so it was about how do you get reading achievement up on a high school level? I was brought in to solve that big huge problem, and it was tough. But the one thing I will say that I was able to do was get every teacher and every department to know that they had to give kids reading strategies in order to, what am I trying to say? Deal with the content. To access the content. Because if you can't read, it doesn't matter what it says in your science book, because you can't read. You might know how a cell works in your head, but if you can't read it, you can't take the test. If you can't take the test, you know the story. I was able to do that, so integrate reading strategies in every content area, and we detracked humanities, which is English, social studies, and then, eventually, freshman biology. If you know how tracking works, kids take a test, and they get placed in a certain class based on that score, and they're in that track that whole four years. You can't get out of it, no matter if you got straight As the whole time you were there. If you get placed in a lower level class, you can never take an honors class, you can never take an AP class, because you're in that track. What we did was we got rid of tracking for those subjects for freshmen, so that, when they were initially placed, if they were able to achieve, then they were able to move up by just merit alone, and they were able to access honors classes and AP classes, and I was very happy about that, because you don't get into the good universities unless you have honors or AP, period. I found that out with my own kids. When we were going to school, it was like, have a good admissions essay, have some decent grades, and get a decent ACT score, right? But now you can have pretty much a top ACT or SAT, you can have a great essay, but if you do not have honors or AP, they don't consider it a college prep curriculum, and you do not have access to those top tier schools. That's the new gatekeeper, it's the AP and honors. Tell your parents that. When they go to high school, make sure they have honors or AP, it doesn't matter. My kid went to St. Rita, and he took three years of science, three years of math, two years of Latin. You know what I mean, I'm like, okay. And he got turned down by DePaul, Loyola, and it was another one, exactly. I'm just like, "Wait a second. What is happening?" But one guy at DePaul finally told me, and I was frustrated, as a parent, my kid is crying every night because he can't get into a college, that that was a new gate. Nobody informed me, but he said, "You don't have an AP or an honors, and that's what they look at now." So who tells the parents, right?

23.words: I'll start in Roslyn, because one of the things that, and I'll be honest with you, I'm not the most personable neighbor. I speak to everybody, but I'm not always trying to go and find all your kids and all that kind of stuff. That's just not me. I'm going to wave at you, how you doing, but I can tell you half the people on my block, and I've been here 20 years, I don't know their names. That's sad, it really is. But I've found that the people that I do know, and, in certain circumstances, they came up and they started talking and they were like, "Well, you know what? I understand these are hard times. I just want to share with you the resource that I have. There's a food bank on the corner." Had no idea. Again, I've been here 20 years. Had no idea there was a food bank on the corner. It was like, "I don't know if you need the services or not, but if you know someone that does, can you please share it?" And I did share it, and there were people that actually went up and utilized it, and I actually even took people over there myself to the food bank for them to utilize that. I was like, oh my goodness, it's that take care of your neighbor that came up. I speak to the gentleman all the time, we wave or whatever, but he was like, "Hey, look, I just want to share this with you, because I know you have kids." He didn't see me leaving out to go to work anymore. Are you being affected by not going to work? Luckily, I can work from home, but he didn't know that. He just thought, "Okay, you might need some help." Stepped up to give me that help and to offer that help. Originally, my parents are from down south, and down south, that's what you did. You helped your neighbor. Everybody in the neighborhood ate. If you had something to eat, you made sure your neighbor had something to eat. That mentality has come back because of COVID-19. I'm seeing that come back. People are sharing resources. I have another neighbor who called me up and said, "Shay, guess what. My sewing machine, I'm going to start making masks. Can I give you guys some?"

31.words: I live in Naperville, and the area in which I live in is diverse in that there are people of color and people that are not of color, but the caveat is the people that are of color, that aren't black, don't identify themselves as people of color. They identify as being white. So it creates a really interesting dynamic. That said, there is a small enclave of people that are here and there's really no place where people can kind of congregate together consistently. But, when I go to the grocery store, I was saying that I see so many black men without face covering. I've seen black women without face covering, and you kind of have to assess the situation before you say things to people, because people are very sensitive these days, but when I feel or find that someone is approachable, I'll talk to them about it, like, "Hey, do you need a mask? What's going on? Have you heard? It's hitting us harder than anybody else. You really need to protect yourself." Beyond my immediate surroundings, and my sister and I share a home, and we are both very much quarantined, because we have underlying conditions, like a lot of people of color, but one of the things I've also done is that I've reached out to, I have a couple of friends that are actually suffering with COVID, and really kind of supporting them with an extended community reach, and making sure that they have what they need, talking to them, checking on them everyday, that sort of thing.

32.words: Wow. Well, I can piggyback to what Shay was saying about the strengths. I've noticed that, and I've lived in my house exactly 20 years, and yes, there's people on the block I don't know, and I've watched new families come in. But there are some folks that live immediately around me that I do know, and so it's sharing the resources, it's like, "Hey, they're going to be giving out masks here." Or "I got this food from a food bank and I have tons of potatoes, do you want them? Or tons of bananas, do you want them?" My neighbor, her kids are eligible to get the meals they're handing out, so she shares whatever they don't use. So it's a lot of sharing, but we were kind of like that before, but it's nice to see it. But the wellbeing check-ins are key. It's kind of like how are you doing, what's going on, how's your extended family, is everybody good? That kind of thing. Sharing stuff like, hey, the Walmart has senior hours, right? And the senior starts at 55, it doesn't start at 60 and up or 65, so you can go. I live right below Beverly, so I was around the Walmart that had COVID-19, I think it was 20 people and two people died. I haven't gone near there in eight weeks.

It's little bits of information like that that get shared about the best way to go about navigating this stuff. But I have seen, when I've driven, not in my own community, but I have seen those little, there used to be those little community libraries, people had those little stands in their yard where you can lend a book, donate a book, borrow a book kind of thing, and people have been putting food in there now instead of books, so I've been seeing that happen, where people who need food can kind of just go and just take the canned goods or whatever. That's been nice. That's been nice. But not seeing, and I've stopped people and said, "Look, man, where's your mask?" Or it was three or four guys kind of congregating outside and I opened up my door and I said, "Hey, six feet apart, you guys," you know what I mean? Even though as soon as I went back inside, they went back to getting closer to each other, but I can only do what I can do. But I think, we have always, as a community of color, like you said, Shay, down south, we've always kind of taken care of each other. We had to. So it's about loaning somebody a couple of eggs if they need it. I remember my mother saying, "Hey, go next door and see if she's got sugar and I'll pay her back when I get it again," that kind of thing, but we've always kind of done that. I think it's with communities that have had everything at their fingertips, I think they're finding it really hard to kind of depend on people or kind of say, "Oh my gosh, I'm out here, I'm anxious, I'm freaking out, what to do next," that kind of thing. We've always had those kind of informal networks where we can call each other, check in on each other, see what each other needs, that kind of thing. And then I see organizations like-

41.words: -While shopping. It was funny, and because I would run into people of color, like black women, and a couple of them said, "Are we underreacting to this? Because you don't see us out here doing what they're doing." People were buying freezers. Freezers, literal freezers. Freezers, like deep freezes like my black family had. What I said to each of those folks was that we're always prepared. This is the same old three, six, nine for us. We've always got a freezer, we're always going to have some backup food, we always have some sort of network [crosstalk 00:28:56]. Just the idea, I was amazed that people were buying cleaning products, because my thought was, "What were you cleaning with before?" It's been an interesting dynamic to watch, for sure. I think the thing too is this is, and that might be one of the problems that we're having and why we're so affected health-wise, because this is not, they keep calling it the new normal. This is not a new normal for us. We've been in survival mode for a long time as the black community.

44.words: I believe that's because this, again, like I said, this is not new to us as a community. It's not new to us, so, again, we've always stayed in survival mode. Even if it comes from our ancestors from down south. We've always stayed in survival mode, so when this happened, it's horrible, but we didn't, I think, panic as much, simply because we've been here for a long time, and I've been listening to different faith-based organizations. My church, even though we can't go to church right now, and I think that's where we're struggling with the fact that we can't all go to church, but the church came to us [inaudible 00:31:24]. 58.words: This is the point I was going to just throw out there. My brother worked for Illinois Department of Human Services probably about, let me see. Over 10 years ago. And we were doing work in Englewood, I was working with some schools, and he actually was working with Englewood, because his job was to go out and tell people in the community of all these grant programs and resources that the state of Illinois offers that people didn't know about. One of his key projects was emergency preparedness, and I remember him giving presentations to people about we are so vulnerable, we don't even know it. If our power grid got taken out, we would be literally in survival mode. There would be no cell phones, there would be no refrigeration for food. There would be no computers, there would be no getting money out of the bank. There would be nothing, so you have to prepare. He would help people figure out how do I prepare for an emergency? I remember people would say, "Wow, that's really interesting," but nobody ever took it seriously. It was kind of like he was "womp womp womp," and people didn't take it seriously. But he kind of planted the seed in me, and now, as I look back 15 years later, I'm like, "Man, you were warning people. You were warning people that things like this could happen." We're not ready, and being prepared for an emergency is a privilege. Like you said, not a lot of us have money to go out to [inaudible] and buy freezers or build bunkers or panic rooms or have all this food stored up. It's really a privilege to be prepared for an emergency. That's a whole 'nother question, how do we get our neighbors prepared? Because this is not the last emergency that's going to happen. Matter of fact, they might start happening closer and closer. So that was something that I kind of thought of. Whose right is it to survive an emergency situation? And it comes down to the ones that have the sweeter privileges. How do poor people survive a national emergency? We don't. Go ahead. I'm sorry?

71.words: My concern is that we won't find a cure in time, so it's going to impact those neighborhoods like North Birmingham, Collegeville, those type of neighborhoods because we have the older residents. Also, the fact that you have the older residents, and a lot of them are scared to go to the hospital because of the coronavirus, but they have other comorbidities that they need to be seeing their doctors for to stay healthy, but they're afraid to go out to seek that help, so they're not seeking the help for the diabetes, the high blood pressure, the heart disease, because they're afraid to go out, so that's my concern. If it's not corona, by them not seeking the medical attention they need to keep themselves healthy and upkeep their health, then they'll be suffering with those things and they'll get worse, which, once again, would make them more susceptible to the coronavirus, because they're actually afraid. That's my concern.

73.words: I don't think coronavirus is going to ease up. I think it's going to continue to intensify, as they indicated. I think what's important is for us to figure out some sort of way to reach these folks to help keep them healthy and to help give them more supports. We're all a vulnerable population, and I do agree with that. I actually have a friend whose brother got sick. She's in another country. Brother got sick, they didn't take him to the hospital because they were afraid of coronavirus. When they finally had to take him to the hospital, he wound up dying, because the team that was there to take care of patients without corona didn't know how to deal with his situation, because they were residents. 39.words: I would have to say my mom. For folks who know me, I'm really close with my mom, she knows pretty much everything. Of course there's some things she won't know. We all take things to the grave, right? probably I know that I can always call on her. We do everything together. I want to be able to always give her the world, and she knows that. It didn't dawn on me until a friend of mine brought it up because we were talking about doing something and that was traveling. I was like, "Oh, can my mom come?" Then it was funny because they kind of paused. Then they were like, "Sure." Then they ended up texting me. They were like, "You know, I know you and your mom are really close, but if you have another friend, it is your birthday, but if you have another friend ..." I was just kind of like, "Oh, okay." Because I just want her to experience and travel because she doesn't always. Growing up she had me at a young age, so she didn't do a lot of that, so if there's an opportunity to do that, I want to be able to experience that with her.

45.words: Healthcare providers listening. Actually listening to what you're saying and not just putting their own kind of take on what you're going through and just assuming that it's something else. It took me about 12 years to figure out that I had fibroids. I had seven pounds and I was in so much pain. Just couldn't see why they can't figure out what's wrong with my stomach. Why is my stomach hurting like this. Why is my menstrual heavy like this? Why does it feel like I'm giving birth every month? It's just crazy that it took that long for me to switch my doctors and say, "I'm no longer talking to you because I'm telling you exactly what's wrong with me and you are the doctor, not me, you have to figure it out. I'm telling you what's wrong." It took me to switch my doctors, and my doctor did one exam and sent me to a specialist and figured out what was wrong with me. Being it took so long and I was in so much pain I had to get a partial hysterectomy. That might have not happened if my doctor actually listened to me and listened to everything that I was telling him that was really wrong with me and not just shooing it off like, "Oh here we go, here's another stomach problem, here's another pain, here take this medicine and be on your way." Just actually listening. Listening to if we say something, that's what it is and it's not to be taken lightly.

Just actually listening.
