46.words: Mine is same. Healthcare providers not listening. My third pregnancy, I think I was nine weeks or something like that and I had this really bad pain. I called urban care, came in like "Oh, it's probably nothing, you're fine." I was like, "No, this is different, this is my third pregnancy, I know something is wrong." Still didn't do anything. Then I went to my doctor, I think it was a week later. She was like, "Oh, no, everything is fine." I ended up going to the E.R. one night just because the pain was so bad, it was in a weird place and so. They did the test where they test your HCG and it's supposed to double every 24 hours, whatever. It was double, and said "Oh no, you're fine. I'm like "No, I need an ultrasound." Something is not right. Finally, I got ultrasound a couple days later and they found that I was pregnant with twins and one of the eggs or whatever embryos was in my fallopian tube and it was on the verge of exploding, so I had to have an emergency DNC to get it out. The thing was it took two weeks. I switched doctors after that. It was crazy because my doctor's like, "Oh no, you're fine, don't worry about it." I'm like, "No, this is my third pregnancy. I know something is wrong," but they just don't believe you. I think especially with black women, there's this notion of, and there's studies that have proved this, that they think that we have a higher pain tolerance or we're out to get some sort of drug or something and so we're faking this. It's just very frustrating because I could have died and there have many women that have died as a result of something similar because the healthcare provider's not listening. I also think there's this misconception that in Wisconsin that the reason why the infant mortality and maternal mortality rates are high is because something about lack of healthcare. It's not about the lack of healthcare. We all have access to healthcare. It's just when we go to the healthcare providers, we're not listened to. Then that prevents people from going because if the doctor's not listening to you, you're not going to want to go back, and then that's why we don't get care. It's not because we don't have access to it. There's just this misconception I think that people just automatically assume why things are happening and don't realize the innate racism that's occurring out the healthcare system.

48.words: I agree with what you both just said about healthcare providers. I feel like most black women have a story about not being listened to. More recently I had a problem with my wrist. It just was in a lot of pain. I thought it was sprained or broken because it was just that much pain and I went to my primary healthcare provider and she ordered X-rays and it wasn't broken or sprained, but it was still in so much pain. I went to a specialist and she was just like, "Oh, it's nothing, it's not really that big of a deal. Just wrap it, wear a brace for a couple months and you'll be fine." I was just kind of like, "Well, this is a lot of pain. This doesn't feel like it's going to be fine, but I'll wear the brace and I'll do what you said." I wear the brace for two months all the time. It did not help at all. I just was kind of afraid to go back to that specialist or just my provider because I don't know what's going on with my wrist, but they weren't offering any type of assistance until last month I finally switched doctors and he just said "Yeah, we're not going to go back to her, we're going to get someone that can listen to you." We found out what the issue was and now it's completely better. I probably wouldn't have had to get shots and steroids in my wrist if they would have just tried to figure out what the problem was in the beginning and actually acknowledge the pain that I was in.

49.words: I guess mines a little different. I haven't had a lot of health care issues. I have some, but for me I just kept looking at the question and reading the question over and over again and I felt like, was like, "Oh I guess I was talking myself into my answer needs to be health related, and it is but not in that sense." The thing that keeps coming to mind was just whiteness gets in the way of being a well black woman. I kept thinking like, "What do I say, what do I say?" It's a lot of stress. Right. I work in a predominantly white organization, just living here in Wisconsin is just I'm not from here and I don't have family here. Right, I mean I have close friends. I have April, I have other close friends. It's my family and I just ... It can be draining always having to prove yourself. Always having to prove your work and your worth. For me, that's what I feel like can get in the way of me being a well black woman because I start having imposter syndrome and second guessing myself and the work that I'm doing and I do extra work. Someone would write a one page paper and I'm writing three page papers. I'm doing all this extra just to makr sure that I'm being respected. Then valued. Right. I think for me, it's a lot about respect. I feel like that's what's gets in the way a lot of times for me being a well black woman. What has put me in a position to now ask which it has been approved, but it's ... I did ask my employer to relocate me to Atlanta to tele-work since we've been doing it for seven months. They approved it, so I will be moving to Atlanta next summer. It's funny, I just got the official letter. We're reading through the book when it's my husband and, of course they put it in there, it'll be discontinued for any reason or no reason. At the end of the day yeah, it's a business, but it's getting me out of here. If that is the case, if six months from when I move if they say we don't have the finances, if they say, I just have to be prepared for that, but at the same time, I'm looking forward to the future and being around more melanin.

44.segment_words: I think for me, it's a lot about respect. I feel like that's what's gets in the way a lot of times for me being a well black woman. What has put me in a position to now ask which it has been approved, but it's ... I did ask my employer to relocate me to Atlanta to tele-work since we've been doing it for seven months.

51.words: I continue this journey, this medical journey. Every time it just adds to the physical ramifications of being black in this community. I think for me it is a mix of culture along with systems that just de-humanize us, will not listen to us, constantly have the criticism when we do speak up. Along with the lack of, and thank goodness, a patient and other organizations for this [inaudible 00:27:40], folks who are coming new to our community and helping to bridge these gaps. The isolation and the aloneness. Everybody says that more often than not is the one thing that tips you from not surviving. It is that isolation that prevents you from actually not even being able to start to survive much less thrive. I think it's a combination of these things. We'll talk at some other point about how you get back to policy and systems changes, but we really do have to work on how the eco-system, black folks, POC folks and white folks are engaging with us all as individuals, because if we don't get that piece, it's going to be, you can have all the policies and practices and stuff written down on paper, but it's not going to help, right? For me, that's super hard. And ...

53.words: Isolation. For sure, I feel isolated. Like what Asia was saying, when I was a kid, they put me I'm a box with a learning disability. That's like, in my own head I know what's going on, I can figure it out, it's just not calculating it the way one plus one is not equaling two to me. It's not calculating right, but you put me in this box over here. That's not working for me because I don't feel like I needed to be in that box. I think you just needed to teach me a different kind of way. They're getting better at it, but there's still, having a learning disability doesn't mean that you can't read. Does not mean that you can't learn. I just learn a different way. I see stuff and letters get mixed around. I put it in its wrong place. They weren't ... No one was trying to figure that part out. I felt isolated. I felt like I didn't belong in a regular class and I for sure didn't belong in a disability class. That goes the same with right now with just my job and just life too. Sometimes I feel like I am isolated. Say I'm playing a game, I feel like I'm playing a different game than everybody else because the way my mind reacts and my mind thinks. It thinks differently. 78.words: [crosstalk 00:44:08]. But what Asia's point, more education. An educational system improving. Then, the other piece both Shaquota and April hit on which is the division that's here in Madison and how we as a community should come together. I think it's also important to understand that it's structured that way because white people want it to be that way. Right, if you're giving one person a dollar, another person 50 cents, then you'll scrabble who's going to get the most money and funding. I think once we all realize that, and I think a lot of us talk about it. It's interesting because I feel like everybody in their circles are talking about it. But at the same time, you have your missions, you're trying to ... Everybody's mission is important and is meeting a need and so I think that's what hard, Is just because it's like your mission is meeting a need. Then, I guess people may feel like if they do come together once again, they're going to get less than, right. I think just speaking for myself, I've been in this community for 12 years. I think I mean the most I've been active in the community is within this last year, maybe two years. That's telling because when I first came, I did try and go, not try, but I went to some of the black networking events. You feel it. Right? 12 years ago when I came I felt like there were these cliques, and I didn't fit in and I did not fit in. Educated or not, I wasn't from here, I'd only been here a little bit of time. I hadn't put in the work. Over time people, yes, got to know me, but then personally my lie began to change and I had a family. I wasn't coming out. It was homework, take care of baby. Now she's older and I'm trying to get back out. A lot of it too is my role. It's allowed me a little bit more flexibility in the community that I work with, they're older. But at the same time it's like there's a missed opportunity personally. I could have made an effort, but at the same time individuals who are in position to make that outreach didn't. I think really making sure that those people that are in positions and not ... What I felt is how some of my alumni feel when they go to white events. They go to a chapter and they're being told, "Oh, are you catering?" Right? It's just a cycle of how we all do it. White people do it to us, we do it to our own people. Right, and so until we understand. Going back to ... It's a lot of things that others said, it's self-love, self-care, just networking, connecting, uplifting, it's just all important. It's like, where do you start? You don't finish. It's a continuation. I think that that's what people are ... It's like, "Okay, we started it, now we're done." Then, we dropped the ball. It's a marathon.
